s.text: While no one suggests that the therapy is ready for widespread clinical application, another way of highlighting current problems is to focus on cost.
While no one suggests that the therapy is ready for widespread clinical application, another way of highlighting current problems is to focus on cost.
While no one suggests that the therapy is ready for widespread clinical application, another way of highlighting current problems is to focus on cost.
While no one suggests that the therapy is ready for widespread clinical application, another way of highlighting current problems is to focus on cost.

In 2000, Dr. James Shapiro and colleagues published a report describing seven consecutive patients who achieved euglycemia following islet transplantation using a steroid-free protocol and large numbers of donor islets, since referred to as the Edmonton protocol [13].
Just as early studies showed islet transplantation's promise, research must now overcome the hurdles revealed by the recent islet transplant experience.

In 2000, Dr. James Shapiro and colleagues published a report describing seven consecutive patients who achieved euglycemia following islet transplantation using a steroid-free protocol and large numbers of donor islets, since referred to as the Edmonton protocol [13].
Since such patients whose diabetes is the most difficult to control have a poor quality of life, islet transplantation offers potential benefit.
Yet despite continued procedural improvements, only about 10% of islet recipients in the late 1990s achieved euglycemia (normal blood glucose).
Although precise figures are not available, over 1 million United States citizens currently live with the disease, with approximately 30,000 new cases diagnosed in the US each year.
Pancreatic islet transplant has offered renewed hope to many patients with diabetes, who envision a life free of glucose checks and insulin injections.
Since such patients whose diabetes is the most difficult to control have a poor quality of life, islet transplantation offers potential benefit.
Yet despite continued procedural improvements, only about 10% of islet recipients in the late 1990s achieved euglycemia (normal blood glucose).
